Will Schofield.Action: Allows Blake to help him stand up by accepting his offered hand.
Remains lying with eyes closed while others prepare to move.
Slowly gets up when Blake offers help, demonstrates awareness of his physical limits yet still prepares to follow orders promptly.
Wears the brass wound stripe indicating prior injury but returns to duty without hesitation.
Hands Blake an envelope with mail when no food was given.
Doesn't mind not receiving mail himself, shows no jealousy.
Shares half of his ham and bread with Blake despite its poor quality.
Light-heartedly encourages Blake with humor about future meals.
Comments resignedly about cancelled leave without complaint, indicating acceptance.
Hands Blake an envelope with mail, keeping organized and aware of communication.
Rummages pockets to find food (ham and bread), showing resourcefulness.
Reassures Blake with positive outlook despite poor food quality, showing emotional steadiness.
Does not get upset over not receiving mail while Blake is excited about it, showing emotional regulation.
Mentions 'I have my uses' when asked about food source, implying skill in acquiring resources.
Shares a light-hearted moment by refusing Blake's bet and teasing him about not having ten bob.
Looks concerned about the situation, showing awareness and implied care for unfolding events.
Engages cooperatively and respectfully with Sergeant Sanders, asking for news sincerely.
Quickly buttons up his tunic to hide any sins underneath.
Salutes and stands at attention respectfully in the presence of his superiors.
Quickly buttons up his tunic, hiding any sins there may be underneath before entering the dugout.
Stands at attention and follows military protocol by handing over his rifle and saluting.
Identifies that the land is held by the Germans when others are uncertain.
Hides his shock after being told about the potential massacre including his brother, remains silent but attentive.
Makes eye contact with Blake questioning the lack of questions but respects Blake’s choice to not respond.
Expresses concern about the mission timing and tries to reason with Blake to wait until dark.
Calls out to Blake to slow down and consider the danger, shows care for his companion.
Does not challenge Erinmore's order directly but voices his realistic worries, showing cautious sincerity.
Gives up trying to stop Blake quickly and follows at a strenuous pace despite his fatigue.
Voices concern about the danger of crossing No Man's Land in daylight, showing caution and awareness of the situation.
Attempts to discuss and reconsider the plan with Blake, indicating thoughtfulness and initiative.
Tries to catch up with Blake who sets a punishing pace, showing physical determination but also lagging behind.
Says 'Sorry' when bumping into a Sergeant, showing politeness and respect.
Grabs Blake's arm to try to persuade him to wait, indicating concern.
Expresses frustration and insists on caution based on past experience, showing sincerity.
Follows Blake despite growing frustration and challenges, showing loyalty and endurance.
Repeats suggestions that contradict orders, causing tension with others, showing stubbornness.
Encourages cautious and clever planning to ensure success and safety of the mission to save Blake’s brother.
Follows Blake closely and stays attentive in dangerous territory, showing loyalty and support.
Experiences fear internally but continues forward despite it, showing restraint and reliability.
Checks watch and calculates time needed for journey, showing planning and awareness.
Encourages Blake to be clever about the mission to increase chances of success.
Follows Blake carefully and remains observant of environment, indicating vigilance.
Briefly loses sight of Blake but quickly works to catch up, recovering from momentary lapse.
Shows internal fear but fights it to continue forward.
Puts himself between Blake and an angry Private to prevent a fight, showing protective intervention.
Speaks levelly to de-escalate a tense situation, commanding respect without aggression.
Steals glances at Blake, showing concern after the confrontation.
Pushes aside a soldier roughly to reach Blake.
Instructs Blake to stay low and carefully moves off a sandbag covering a dead sergeant to avoid disrespect.
Commands Blake to 'Stay low' and carefully maneuvers over rubble, keeping his head below the parapet.
Quickly moves off a sandbag with a dead soldier’s blood staining it, showing situational awareness and respect.
Acts decisively and confidently in a dangerous, chaotic environment with clear commands.
Politely wakes Lieutenant Leslie and respectfully delivers orders despite Leslie's ill health and delirium.
Engages Leslie with patience and does not show frustration despite tense situation and Leslie’s irritability.
Approaches Lieutenant Leslie cautiously, confirms situation, and communicates clearly despite tense circumstances.
Shows uncertainty when asking Leslie if the brass are wrong about the enemy's position.
Stares at Lieutenant Leslie with silent anger when Leslie cynically comments about medals for widows.
Does not engage in Leslie's bitterness, remains focused on the task at hand.
Stares down Lieutenant Leslie intimidatingly, showing resolve and confidence in the face of disrespect and tough talk.
Methodically prepares himself while Blake uses the periscope, demonstrating focus and readiness.
Politely asks 'Any cover, Sir? Anywhere to jump off from?'
Acknowledges lack of flare gun when asked to send up a flare, but stays focused and cooperative
Goes first over the parapet despite shaking hands to protect Blake, showing care and willingness to shield a comrade.
Leads the way out of the trench first, despite visible fear and shaking hands, demonstrating resolve and courage under extreme stress.
Assesses the environment carefully, moving stealthily and observing the wire and terrain before proceeding.
Nods to Blake’s concern acknowledging injury but reassures him he is fine.
Gestures to Blake to stay calm when Blake panics at the dead German soldier's body.
Leads and encourages Blake to keep moving toward their goal, showing reassurance and steadiness.
Grabs at the corpse unintentionally when steadying himself, showing practical focus rather than squeamishness.
Calmly gestures to Blake to stay calm when Blake panics after encountering a rat-chewed corpse.
Leads the movement out of the sap trench carefully and cautiously, taking the lead and advancing crouched low while watching for danger.
Commands Blake to stay still and hides effectively in a shell-hole when planes approach, demonstrating tactical awareness.
Accidentally puts wounded hand into the putrid flesh of the dead German soldier, showing momentary lapse in situational awareness.
Pours water on Blake's bleeding hand and helps bandage it using his teeth while Blake keeps watch.
Shares a moment of quiet understanding with Blake while observing the smoldering embers, indicating shared concern and alertness.
Follows Blake without hesitation despite his own injured hand, showing trust and solidarity.
Takes care to bandage his bleeding hand quickly and continues moving forward despite injury, wrapping the bandage with his teeth while maintaining awareness of the surroundings.
Observes the still-glowing embers in the brazier and deduces the enemy has not been gone long, showing attention to detail and situational awareness.
Moves cautiously through unfamiliar, possibly dangerous German trenches, demonstrating careful and deliberate actions.
Pauses and stares at a photograph of a wife and child left behind by the Germans.
Carefully checks the trench ahead for threats, moves with rifle ready, cautious advance.
Assesses that the trench is blocked and seeks alternative routes by exploring the dugout.
Quickly follows Blake into potentially dangerous and unstable terrain (timber stairs), demonstrating presence of mind and adaptability.
Pauses to notice a personal photograph among the abandoned German quarters, showing emotional sensitivity but no clear direct impact on immediate task competence.
Warns Blake about the trip wire and tells him not to move.
Comments humorously on the size and cockiness of the rat.
Critiques Blake’s implied hunger with a gentle tease ('You cannot be that hungry').
Identifies the tunnel as a way through, showing practical navigation skills.
Notices the large rat and the hanging food sacks, demonstrating alertness to environment.
Discovers the crate of food tins and recognizes the writing, indicating knowledge and observational skills.
Detects and warns Blake about the trip wire, preventing immediate danger.
Sustains an explosion’s impact and cries out in muffled screams, showing vulnerability but reliance on his comrade Blake.
Does not abandon or show resentment towards Blake despite being buried and in peril; dependent and trusting.
Remains standing close to a dangerous wire despite the surrounding instability, ultimately getting buried in a collapse.
Allows himself to be helped by Blake and struggles in shock but does not panic or turn on Blake.
Thrashes and struggles to free himself but does not push Blake away or reject help.
No signs of aggression, selfishness, or abandonment during the rescue.
Struggles to free himself from tightly packed debris but is overcome by shock and physical incapacity.
After being pulled free by Blake, manages to stand and follow toward the tunnel entrance despite extreme physical distress.
Despite being blinded and terrified, he trusts Blake and leaps across the mineshaft when urged to jump.
Frozen and unable to act initially during the jump, showing vulnerability and reliance on others.
Is paralyzed and blinded, hesitates to jump over the mineshaft, struggles to see and trust his companion.
Overcomes fear and blindness to leap across the mineshaft and survives the jump, manages to cling on and move forward despite impaired vision and the collapsing tunnel.
Drops down beside Blake to rest, shares moment of vulnerability and physical struggle.
Turns sharply on Blake after his comment about shooting the rat, expressing frustration.
Admits his fear and trembling openly by checking his shaking hands and tobacco tin.
Responds bitterly to Blake’s comment about choosing him, revealing distrust and resentment.
Struggles physically (bent double, shakily following) and shows visible signs of strain (shaking hands), appears unsettled.
Attempts to clear dust from eyes using water from canteen, showing practical response under discomfort.
Displays frustration and self-doubt openly, questioning Blake's choice to partner with him.
Despite physical strain and emotional agitation, continues forward with mission, following Blake cautiously.
Turns sharply when 'home' is mentioned, indicating sensitivity but also emotional restraint.
Softens his expression when Blake talks about the mission being harder than expected.
Commands Blake to fire the flare despite harsh circumstances, showing trust and leadership.
Engages in practical conversation and shares strategic thoughts with Blake, indicating cooperation and sincerity.
Firmly tells Blake not to mention going home, showing emotional control and focus on the mission.
Calmly instructs Blake to fire the flare to signal British lines, demonstrating decisive action under pressure.
Asks Blake if he knows their location and assesses the terrain, showing situational awareness and use of navigational skills.
Notes the destruction of their own trenches, concluding it was intended to trap them, indicating insight and tactical understanding.
Shares a quiet laugh with Blake at the rat-ear story despite tension.
Keeps focus on the surroundings despite Blake's attempts to engage him otherwise, directing attention to the trees and maintaining watchfulness.
Is still shaking slightly, indicating some residual stress or nervousness.
Responds to Blake's story with questions and engagement, showing mental alertness.
Begins to laugh quietly, showing ability to maintain composure and morale.
Compliments Blake by saying he deserves a medal for rescuing a comrade.
Swaps his medal for a bottle of wine and shows indifference when Blake suggests the medal should be honored or given to family.
Ignores Blake’s emotional appeal about the meaning of the medal and men dying for it, offering no response.
Shows vulnerability by admitting he hated going home and felt torn about leaving family behind.
Dismisses the medal as 'just a bit of bloody tin' and downplays its importance.
Does not respond to Blake's initial appeals about sacrifice and honor, indicating emotional reservedness.
Turns and walks ahead decisively after an emotional moment, showing control over his feelings and focus on the mission.
Dismisses the medal as 'just a bit of bloody tin' indicating a pragmatic and realistic attitude rather than sentimental distraction.
Chokes up and struggles with emotions briefly but recovers quickly and continues forward.
Fails to engage more deeply or offer more supportive responses to Blake's emotional statements, potentially missing an opportunity for leadership or morale-building.
Registers Blake's homesickness and shows attentiveness to his companion's feelings.
Leads cautiously through unknown terrain, ensuring safety for both.
Shows anxiety about the abandoned farmhouse.
Leads cautiously, scans the environment carefully, keeps rifle raised, and splits up with Blake to check the farmhouse strategically.
Notices the child’s doll with cigarette burns on its eyes and pauses to look at it thoughtfully.
Moves through trashed areas silently, not expressing anger or bitterness despite damage to civilian property.
Shares the discovery of milk with Blake quietly, without boasting or claiming credit.
Shares moment of watching planes with Blake, calmly observes and comments on dogfight outcome.
Immediately retreats to avoid the incoming plane to protect himself and others.
Follows Blake into the burning barn to rescue the injured pilot despite the danger.
Tears open the pilot’s strap and helps pull the pilot from the burning wreckage.
Drags the severely injured enemy pilot to safety, showing concern beyond enemy lines.
Recognizes the danger of the low-flying plane and immediately begins to retreat toward safety.
Alongside Blake, takes quick initiative to rescue the burning pilot from the crashed plane despite personal risk.
Works quickly to provide water to the dying pilot despite the language barrier, showing concern and urgency.
Fires two shots to kill the pilot after the pilot stabs Blake, acting decisively to protect his friend.
Works the water pump efficiently to help the injured pilot despite the difficult situation.
Quickly reacts to the threat by firing two shots into the attacking pilot to protect Blake.
Shows confusion and fear after the attack on Blake, which could indicate momentary uncertainty.
Tries to stop Blake's bleeding and calms him despite Blake's pain and resistance.
Insists on carrying Blake and getting to aid despite Blake's protests and danger.
Persists in helping Blake even when Blake lashes out violently and rejects help.
Attempts to stop Blake's bleeding by applying a dressing and physically trying to stem the blood flow.
Encourages Blake repeatedly to stand and keep moving despite Blake's pain and resistance.
Decides to carry Blake to the Aid Post alone after realizing no help is nearby.
Perseveres in dragging Blake despite his violent resistance and worsening blood loss.
Shows desperation and anxiety, which may suggest emotional strain impacting calm, calculated decision making.
Swaps Blake’s blood-soaked dressing for a fresh one despite panic.
Encourages Blake to keep moving and insists on continuing despite Blake’s weakening condition.
Physically attempts to lift and carry Blake despite great effort and pain.
Looks desperately around for help, showing concern and a desire to aid Blake further.
Looks down at Blake unsure how to answer his question about being hit (hesitation, possibly avoids comforting lies).
Swaps Blake’s blood-soaked dressing for a fresh one under pressure.
Encourages Blake to keep moving despite his weakening state.
Attempts to physically lift and carry Blake despite Blake being a dead weight, showing determination but ultimately failing.
Looks around for help but finds none, appearing helpless.
Maintains focus on the mission to find Blake’s brother, despite the deteriorating situation.
Unsure how to answer Blake’s question about being hit and the fire, showing uncertainty.
Holds down Blake’s wound, comforts him in his last moments, promises to write to Blake’s mother, and holds Blake’s hand as he dies.
Stems Blake's bleeding effectively, holds his hand during his last moments, provides comforting presence and clear directions about the route to take.
Unsure how to answer Blake's initial question about the wound.
Unable to find words to soothe Blake when he asks for reassurance.
Cradles Blake's head after he dies, showing care and sorrow.
Takes Blake's rings and identity disc respectfully, leaves photo on his heart.
Rummages through Blake's pockets to secure the message despite distress.
Does not verbally respond to Privates' questions about what happened, appears lost and shocked.
Snaps out of shock and quickly retrieves the message from Blake’s pocket, safely storing it despite blood smudges.
Recognizes the map is illegible due to blood saturation and discards it to avoid confusion.
Handles identification items carefully—takes rings and identity disc, and respectfully preserves the photograph.
Struggles physically to move Blake’s dead body, showing determination despite emotional weight.
Fails to verbally communicate or explain what happened to the privates when questioned, remaining withdrawn.
Kneels beside Blake's body, unwilling to leave him immediately, showing respect and sorrow.
Wipes blood from his hands using grass, a quiet, considerate gesture.
Follows orders from Captain Smith without argument, indicating respect and cooperation.
Delivers an urgent message to stop the attack despite emotional difficulty from Blake’s death.
Initially hesitates to move after Blake’s body but ultimately follows orders and proceeds with the mission.
Respectfully answers Colonel Collins' inquiry and allows Smith to explain his presence without interruption.
Walks with Captain Smith past the trucks and quietly observes the soldiers without complaint or negative comment.
Responds clearly and respectfully to Colonel Collins about his identity and mission, demonstrating awareness of military protocol and situation.
Passively watches and takes in the environment as they approach the trucks without overtly taking initiative or offering solutions.
Responds respectfully and concisely to Captain Smith's condolences about his friend.
Sits silently among the soldiers without initiating conversation or trying to engage with them.
Makes space for himself quietly without complaint despite being crammed in the truck.
Nods respectfully when Captain Smith apologizes about his friend and does not dwell on the loss.
Makes space for himself quietly among the other soldiers in the cramped truck without causing disturbance.
Remains silent and observant during the tension and grumbling among soldiers rather than engaging in unnecessary talk.
Pulls his tunic tight around himself and almost disappears into the noise of the men, appearing withdrawn as others joke and laugh.
Is silently enduring the rowdiness of the men, showing no engagement with their teasing or jesting.
Pulls his tunic tight around himself and almost disappears into the noise of the men, remains still and silent while the men are rowdy and mocking.
Checks his wristwatch quietly after the laughter settles.
Takes initiative to solve the problem of the stuck truck by instructing the driver and encouraging men to get out and push together.
Pushes hard alongside men despite difficulty, showing perseverance and solidarity.
Shows impatience and frustration when men hesitate to move quickly, raising his voice with 'Come on!'.
Checks his wristwatch to keep track of time, showing awareness and responsibility.
Recognizes that the driver should reverse to attempt unsticking the truck and gives clear instructions to do so.
Orders all men to get out of the vehicle to attempt pushing, trying to organize efforts under pressure.
Encourages and pushes the men to work together physically and does not give up despite no initial success.
Some men are slow to respond and reluctant but Schofield maintains firmness, showing leadership in managing unmotivated subordinates.
Fails to get the truck free despite prolonged effort, indicating limitations but persists instead of giving up.
Refuses to give up and insists everyone push together despite exhaustion, showing determination and rallying the men.
Expresses desperation openly, showing vulnerability to inspire others to help.
Struggles with emotions, trying not to cry; others notice and offer support, indicating his sincerity and trustworthiness.
After the truck moves, he immediately urges the men to get back in quickly, showing care for their safety and the mission.
Refuses to consider the advice to get wood under the wheels because of time constraints, pressing onward with sheer effort.
Leads by example, shouting encouragement and rallying the men to push together despite extreme physical exertion.
Continues pushing the truck out of the ditch with determination, ultimately succeeding.
Falls into the mud and struggles emotionally after success, but regains composure quickly and insists on moving forward.
Acknowledges the gravity of his mission openly and calmly with the men.
Accepts whisky offered by Butler and thanks him politely.
Maintains composure and confidence even when Cooke doubts him.
Clearly states mission objectives and situation to other soldiers, maintaining calm and confidence under pressure.
Accepts whisky from another soldier, showing composure and social ease within the group.
Mentally checks that the important letter is still in his pocket amidst tense conversation, demonstrating responsibility and attentiveness.
Responds confidently to doubt expressed by others about his chances of success ('Yes. I will.'), showing determination but not necessarily skill or strategy.
Checks carefully that the letter is still in his pocket and puts it back in his tobacco tin, showing responsibility and care.
Wishes the others good luck before leaving the truck, conveying sincerity and friendly goodwill.
Responds politely and appreciatively to wishes of good luck from fellow soldiers and Captain Smith.
Firmly insists he cannot divert route despite Captain Smith’s suggestion, prioritizing mission over flexibility.
Affirms to Captain Smith that the orders are direct and will be followed, showing respect and reliability.
Insists on not diverting the route despite Captain Smith's suggestion, stating he doesn't have the time.
Acknowledges and respects Captain Smith’s advice but remains firm on his mission priority.
Surveys the environment carefully upon reaching the canal and the destroyed bridge, showing awareness of his surroundings.
Carefully and persistently navigates a dangerous broken bridge under enemy fire to cross a canal and reach safety.
Carefully crosses a broken and dangerous bridge despite risk and injury, showing physical skill and courage.
Uses cover and stealth to assess the shooter's location before engaging, demonstrating tactical awareness.
Struggles to load and steady his rifle due to injury and shaking hands, showing reduced effectiveness under stress.
Engages in intense combat to neutralize threat, showing determination to survive and complete mission.
Carefully and quietly approaches enemy, steadies his aim under extreme physical distress and cold, successfully suppresses enemy fire and advances into enemy position.
Moves cautiously and uses cover effectively while clearing the lock house, showing tactical awareness.
Engages in shootout with wounded enemy soldier, quickly reacts to threat, but ultimately gets shot and falls down stairs.
After being injured and disoriented, Schofield struggles to regain composure and locate his rifle, showing determination to continue his mission.
Moves cautiously and silently, trying to avoid danger and protect himself.
Flings himself down into rubble and lies motionless, breathing heavily, to avoid being seen under flare light and gunfire.
Waits patiently for flare light to die before moving again, minimizing exposure.
Does not stop running when a flare approaches, instead swiftly darts into cover.
Carefully peeks out and checks both directions before entering the market street, showing cautious assessment of surroundings.
Moves cautiously and warily through dangerous, heavily shelled ruins rather than rushing.
Stops and attempts to identify the approaching man before reacting.
Responds quickly to threat by running and hiding instead of engaging recklessly.
Cautiously approaches unknown flicker of flame with rifle ready, prepared but not aggressive.
Quickly identifies the threat when the man turns out to be a German soldier and immediately runs to evade.
Successfully uses nearby environmental features (coal chute) to escape a pursuing enemy, demonstrating quick thinking and spatial awareness.
Remains calm and silent in pitch black coal cellar while enemy passes by, showing patience and presence of mind.
Carefully readies his weapon and proceeds cautiously towards an unknown potential threat behind a curtain, indicating tactical awareness and preparedness.
Sets down rifle and raises hands to show he means no harm to Lauri, calming her fear; speaks gently and tries to communicate despite language barrier.
Enters woman's hiding place cautiously with gun raised at first.
Closes his eyes and relaxes against Lauri's caring touch, thanks her quietly.
Understands enough French to obey Lauri's instructions despite injury and nausea.
Sways initially but makes the effort to follow guidance and sit down as directed.
Passively allows Lauri to tend to his wound, relaxing against her touch.
Smiles upon seeing the baby, kneels down quietly beside them, attempts to help by offering his food rations generously despite not fully understanding the needs.
Shows genuine concern and patience while interacting gently with the baby and Lauri, even when communication is difficult.
Responds with kindness by giving up water from his canteen when he realizes the baby needs milk.
Recognizes the baby needs special care and offers his rations, demonstrating resourcefulness and concern.
Initially does not understand the baby's dietary needs until Lauri explains milk is needed, showing a momentary gap in knowledge.
Responds quickly by offering his canteen water when he realizes the baby needs milk, showing adaptability and willingness to act despite limited resources.
Calms and soothes a baby by softly reciting a poem to settle it.
Does not verbally engage with Lauri Lauri beyond necessary communication, focusing primarily on the baby and his own mission.
Speaks softly and calmly to soothe the baby, successfully settling it with a poem.
Keeps calm while counting distant clock strikes to monitor time and danger, showing situational awareness.
Ignores local advice to stay hidden until daylight, deciding to leave despite higher risk of being seen.
Says 'I'm sorry' before leaving, indicating regret or politeness.
Stays silent and hidden, does not engage with suffering German soldier (Private Muller) who is drunk and vomiting.
Moves cautiously through a damaged house and silent streets, staying in shadows to avoid detection.
Carefully hides and waits silently when encountering a blind drunk enemy soldier, showing patience and tactical awareness.
Shows uncertainty when reaching a crossroads and being momentarily lost before choosing a direction.
Suppresses Baumer's scream to avoid exposing their presence, wrestles the knife away despite pain, risking further harm to himself to maintain stealth.
Fights desperately to restrain Baumer from being caught by Muller, despite physical pain and exhaustion.
Immediately acts to protect Baumer by diverting Muller and fleeing to draw attention away.
Struggles physically but continues to hold Baumer and maintain focus despite pain and exhaustion.
Quickly abandons rifle to flee when Baumer loses consciousness and enemy approaches, demonstrating situational awareness and adaptability.
Leaps out of shadows and charges past Muller to escape, showing decisiveness and courage under pressure.
Runs without stopping despite being chased and under fire, showing stamina and determination but also a potential risk of exhaustion or injury.
Manages to stay afloat after losing heavy webbing and uses the current to navigate the river.
Attempts to pull himself up on a felled tree but is overpowered by the torrent.
Fails to see an approaching large rock and is slammed against it, causing disorientation.
Recognizes the sound of the waterfall and braces himself before going over it.
Thrashes and tries to swim to the bank in panic as the rapids get faster.
Surfaces after going over the waterfall, manages to turn onto his back and grabs a branch to stay afloat.
Climbs over the bodies of soldiers and civilians to save himself and continue his mission.
Fights to regain consciousness and mobility despite near-drowning and severe physical exhaustion.
Assessing the environment instinctively and deciding to swim toward the bank when the current slows.
Using the fallen tree and bodies as a makeshift bridge to climb out of the river.
Cries openly for Blake, the baby, and life itself, showing emotional vulnerability.
Listens silently and respectfully to the young soldier’s song with other men, showing openness and receptiveness.
Leans against a tree and sits on the outskirts of the group, showing some social withdrawal or uncertainty.
Despite extreme exhaustion and emotional distress, he forces himself to get up and continue moving toward the sound of music, showing resilience and determination.
Stops and slumps against a tree, uncertain of his surroundings and questioning his own state, reflecting a moment of hesitation and vulnerability.
Weakly communicates his urgent mission despite disorientation, showing trust in others by asking for help.
Disbelief upon learning the soldiers around him are the Devons, indicating cautiousness but no hostility.
Does not immediately bond or express friendliness toward the other soldiers but does not reject or act coldly either.
Pushes and barges through throngs of soldiers to deliver a crucial message, urgently trying to prevent unnecessary loss of life.
Insists and pleads with the Lieutenant not to send men over in attack, showing concern for their safety.
His frantic and desperate demeanor while delivering the message suggests sincerity and earnestness to protect others.
Runs along the comms trench urgently, pushing through crowds to deliver an important message about the attack being called off.
Attempts to communicate direct orders from Army command despite skepticism and hostility from the officers.
Pushes through dense, crowded trenches with urgency to deliver an important message, showing determination and focus under pressure.
Attempts to stop the Captain from proceeding with the attack by delivering a crucial message, demonstrating situational awareness and responsibility.
Does not display hesitation or confusion when confronted with the Captain’s terrified state, maintaining composure and trying to handle the situation.
Grabs Ivins's arms to try to communicate in chaos, pushes forward through danger to find Colonel Mackenzie.
Leaves Ivins behind when blown apart by a shell without hesitation, focuses on continuing mission.
Pushes through a wall of men blocking the trench to advance the mission despite danger.
Urgently tries to convey important orders to Lieutenant Richards, showing concern for the chain of command and overall safety.
Climbs onto the firing step to make a dangerous move over open ground, appearing reckless but driven by commitment.
Keeps moving towards an impassable trench despite the danger and chaos, pushing past a sergeant trying to regain order, and attempts to communicate urgent orders despite confusion.
Climbs onto the firing step in open ground under heavy shelling, a risky and potentially reckless move that suggests desperation rather than calculated skill.
Runs unarmed across No Man’s Land under heavy fire to deliver a message, despite the extreme danger.
Despite being unarmed and exposed in No Man's Land under heavy fire, Schofield chooses to run full speed towards the target trench, showing determination and physical endurance.
Stumbles and falls halfway through but immediately gets up and continues running without hesitation.
Disregards safety by leaving cover unarmed, putting himself at great risk, which could jeopardize mission success.
Insists on getting through to Colonel Mackenzie to stop a misguided attack, pushing past orderlies despite exhaustion.
Attempts to push through orderlies to deliver an important message to Colonel Mackenzie despite physical exhaustion and opposition.
Fails to persuade orderlies to let him pass, losing physical strength and getting removed from the dugout area.
Forces his way into Mackenzie's dugout to deliver urgent stop orders despite resistance.
Pleads earnestly with Colonel Mackenzie to read orders and stop attack to save lives.
Insists Colonel Mackenzie read the warning letter despite initial dismissal.
Waits patiently and respectfully while Mackenzie reads the letter, showing calm under pressure.
Insists Colonel Mackenzie read the intercepted letter to prevent a misguided attack, demonstrating awareness and presence of mind.
Waits patiently and calmly while the Colonel reads the letter, showing self-control and confidence in his judgement.
Acknowledges praise from Major Hepburn politely and sincerely.
Looks for Lieutenant Blake to find and possibly help him.
Passes through wounded soldiers without engaging or being acknowledged, appearing like a ghost.
Maintains composure when confronted by Colonel Mackenzie and Major Hepburn, responds politely and respectfully.
Seeks information proactively about Lieutenant Blake despite the confusion and trauma around him.
Freezes momentarily after being ordered to get medical attention, showing some hesitation.
Moves through chaotic and dangerous trench environment without being noticed, showing situational awareness.
Insists on finding Lieutenant Blake among the wounded despite being repeatedly turned away, shows concern and persistence.
Appears sick with failure and hopeless after not finding Blake, showing a sincere emotional response.
Persistently searches for Lieutenant Blake despite confusion and initial dead ends, showing determination and focus under pressure.
Engages medical personnel and navigates a chaotic field station effectively to fulfill his mission.
Appears shaky and nearly overwhelmed upon finally finding Blake, showing momentary physical weakness and emotional strain.
Offers to write to Lieutenant Blake's mother to tell her that Tom wasn’t alone.
Speaks sincerely about Tom, sharing that he was a good man and saved Schofield's life.
Gently delivers the bad news about Tom's death and shows respect by handing over possessions.
After delivering the news, appears emotionally affected and unsure where to go, suggesting internal struggle rather than coldness.
Looks at photographs of his wife and daughters, showing love and longing.
